ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Not only learned Japanese but also learned more about Japanese culture

reading primary documents (short story, novel, anime) in Japanese 
debate skills and etiquette in Japanese
I believe that my conversational skills in Japanese improved the most. I also think that my reading skills got better as well.
My vocabulary and grammar knowledge in Japanese have improved.

I enhanced my skills in speaking, writing, and especially reading Japanese. This course taught me that I am capable of understanding anything in Japanese with the right research, tools and motivation.
Learned advanced grammar, also improved reading, listening, and speaking skills. Learned a large number of new kanji.
I learned how to further my Japanese skills and apply them in writing and speaking. I was also able to better my reading skills in terms of speed and comprehension.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: No. It is perfect.

The class uses a variety of media instead of just following straight a textbook. We looked at an anime, a movie, new articles, and short stories. The workload is high and there's a lot of prep to do outside of class because this class only meets twice a week.

strengths: focus and practice on reading and grammar 
weaknesses: not a lot of focus on writing in Japanese (we only had one essay writing exercise); there was a lot of homework (~5 hrs per week) but they were not the most intellectually challenging/stimulating; the class was too big with 18 students so difficult to participate and get individual attention; Stever sensei can be disorganized and often forgets to upload homework assignments on time; maybe it's just how it gets with higher-level language classes, but I can't pinpoint if/how my Japanese has improved after the class; mostly because the weekly discussion topics were kind of random for example one week on anime and another on Japanese news: there was little coherence in how they connect to each other

Strength: Stever-sensei is a great teacher. She's very receptive to questions and will make sure that each student understands the readings. The course was the right amount of work. Plus, the conversation clinics/practice-sessions were really helpful for me because of their flexible nature.

Weakness: I do wish we had worked a bit more on our writing and listening comprehension. I know that adding it would have felt like a lot of work, so I understand why it wasn't as robust. However, I think a few in-class exercises would have been helpful. I also think that submitting homework online through Canvas made getting feedback on assignments a lot less clear. It's hard to follow the corrections on Canvas. Half the time, the platform couldn't even process Japanese, so the corrections would just show up as wingdings or indecipherable symbols. Next year, I would really appreciate it if Stever-sensei went back to doing homework on paper.
I like that this course pushes you to apply what youve learned in earlier levels through reading, listening and discussing. It felt like it progressed naturally from L4.

The course had very few weaknesses if any. Classes were mostly discussion-based and hence very engaging. Homework and readings (which were very manageable) served as the primer for class discussion and were fulfilling in their own right.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. The course design is very interesting, there will be Japanese debates which are  my favorite
Yes, if they are interested in further their Japanese study. This class really focuses on discussions on various topics.
Yes, it's a good course to continue learning Japanese with. Plus, it is a lot less of a commitment than L1-L4.
Yes, if you are interested in improving your writing and conversational abilities in Japanese
Yes! I feel I learned a lot and improved greatly in my Japanese skills.

Yes, if you like learning Japanese, this is a good way to continue your skills. You get out from this class what you put in. Many of the homework materials are interesting as well, so they are fun to engage with.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student who is motivated to continue expanding/improving their Japanese skills. To an extent, what you get out of this course is how you choose to make of it. Homework, for one, is largely completion-based, but oftentimes I would spend time answering the questions thoughtfully while applying grammar/vocab that I recently learned; this enabled more meaningful/constructive feedback that was much more conducive to my learning than if I had put less thought in the assignment. A lot of the other marks come from the two tests (which were very fair in my opinion) and some occasional activities. In short, you have little to lose in the class, and I think that aspect allowed me and many other students to take it one step further to challenge ourselves when we had the time.
